metadata./Title: Coexisting parathyroid adenoma, thyroid carcinoma, and tuberculosis of thyroid: a case report
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Background:
Background Coexisting parathyroid adenoma, thyroid carcinoma, and tuberculosis of thyroid is a very rare phe nomenon. Primary thyroid tuberculosis is itself very rare despite high global prevalence of tuberculosis in developing 
countries. Majority of thyroid tuberculosis identified in postoperative histopathology or cytopathology. The coexist ence of thyroid cancer with tuberculosis or parathyroid adenoma has been reported in the literature but not a single 
case of the three pathologies coexisting together has been found in the literature published. We are presenting a rare 
case of a constellation of synchronous parathyroid adenoma, thyroid carcinoma, and thyroid tuberculosis. This case 
report will provoke researchers to work on understanding the association of hypercalcemia or chronic inflammation 
leading to development of malignancy or parathyroid adenoma in the presence of hypothyroidism will give future 
perspective in managing such patients.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation A Islam lady aged 45 years old, diagnosed with hypothyroidism, was evaluated for pregnancy loss 
and rapid weight gain from 13 years back and started on tablets of levothyroxine 25 µg once daily. She was doing well 
until the past 2 years; there after she noticed insidious onset of a swelling over anterior aspect of right side of the neck 
and bone pain in back and lower limbs. Patient underwent routine investigations and was found to have raised serum 
calcium (11.4 mg/dl) and parathyroid hormone (253 pg/ml). Anti-thyroid peroxidase (TPO) and anti-thyroglobulin 
(Tg) level were normal. Ultrasounds showed multiple nodules in both lobe of thyroid and left inferior parathyroid 
adenoma. The patient underwent total thyroidectomy with left inferior parathyroidectomy, and final histopathology 
showed features of subacute granulomatous thyroiditis along with hurthle cell change in right lobe of thyroid. The 
left lobe additionally showed necrotizing epitheloid cell granulomas, which on Zeihl–Neelson staining revealed presence of acid-fast bacilli. Sections from the isthmus show a focus of papillary thyroid microcarcinoma. The left inferior 
parathyroid gland sent as a frozen sample was found to be parathyroid adenoma. On 6-month follow-up, the patient 
was feeling much relief in bone pain and tolerating antitubercular drugs uneventfully.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion Coexistence of parathyroid adenoma, nonmedullary thyroid carcinoma, and thyroid tuberculosis 
is extremely rare. Surgery is curative for hyper parathyroidism and thyroid carcinoma. Thyroid tuberculosis responds 
well to current antitubercular drugs. Its etiology needs to be explored more; the probable hypothesis is chronic 
inflammation due to latent tuberculosis might leads to development of thyroid carcinoma and parathyroid adenoma. 
Further studies need to be done for better understanding of underlying mechanism and better management options 
for such patients. To the best of our knowledge, similar cases have not been reported.Open Access

Background
Coexistence of parathyroid adenoma, thyroid 
carcinoma, and tuberculosis of the thyroid is a very 
rare phenomenon. Primary thyroid tuberculosis is 
itself very rare, despite high global prevalence of 
tuberculosis in developing countries. The majority 
of thyroid tuberculosis cases are identified in 
postoperative histopathology or cytopathology. The 
coexistence of thyroid cancer with tuberculosis or 
parathyroid adenoma has been reported earlier in the 
literature but not a single case of coexistence of the 
three pathologies together at the same time has been 
published yet. In general, long-term inflammatory 
diseases may offer the right conditions for malignant 
transformations. Mycobacterial infections are well 
known to cause persistent and chronic inflammation. 
In accordance with research studies, mycobacterial 
cell wall components are capable of inducing DNA 
damage through the production of nitric oxide and 
reactive oxygen species. This DNA damage has been 
linked to the initiation of cancers that are associated 
to inflammation. A small number of studies have 
demonstrated that hypercalcemia can also lead to the 
development of cancer.
In this case report we are presenting a rare case of 
the constellation of synchronous parathyroid adenoma, 
thyroid carcinoma, and thyroid tuberculosis. This 
case study will encourage researchers to investigate 
the relationship between chronic inflammation or 
hypercalcemia and the development of cancer or 
parathyroid adenoma, since it will provide insight into 
how to treat these patients in the future.Case presentation
A Islam lady aged 45  years was already diagnosed with 
hypothyroidism during her evaluation for pregnancy loss 
and rapid weight gain 13  years back, for which she was 
started on tablets of levothyroxine 25 µg once daily. She 
was doing fine 2 years back when she noticed an insidious 
onset of swelling over the anterior aspect of right 
side of the neck and pain in her lower back and lower 
limbs. There was no history of rapid increase in size, 
associated pain, fever, hypothyroidism/hyperthyroidism, 
compressive symptoms, metastatic symptoms, and 
swelling anywhere else in the body. There was no history 
of abdominal pain, muscle weakness, and altered mood.
On examination: she was an average-built lady with 
body mass index (BMI) of 28  kg/m2, with stable vitals, 
there was no pallor, generalized lymphadenopathy, and 
pedal edema. Neck examination showed diffuse enlarge ment of both lobes of the thyroid gland (right > left) with 
well-defined mobile, firm and nontender swelling of 
4 cm × 3 cm in right lobe of thyroid and another swelling 
of around 1 cm × 1 cm on the left side of the neck; both 
swellings were moving up with deglutition and not with 
protrusion of tongue (Fig.  1a). There was retrosternal 
extension, tracheal deviation, and cervical lymphadenop athy. Respiratory, abdominal, and cardiovascular systems 
were found to be in normal range. The patient underwent 
cholecystectomy and hysterectomy 9  years back for gall 
stone disease and vaginal bleeding, of which histopathol ogy was not available. She is taking mix diet with normal 
bowel and bladder habits. There was no history of similar 
disease in the family.
On routine investigation it was discovered that the 
patient had elevated levels of calcium (11.4  mg/dl) and Keywords  Thyroid tuberculosis, Thyroid cancer, Parathyroid adenoma, Co-existing, Chronic inflammation,

parathyroid hormone (253 pg/ml) in their serum. Other 
routine blood tests were normal values as shown in 
Table 1.
On further evaluation with imaging, ultrasound 
showed a well-defined hyperechoic lesion (wider than 
taller) with peripheral halo measuring 25 mm × 18  mm 
without any internal vascularity and calcification in right 
lobe of thyroid (Thyroid Imaging Reporting and Data 
System; TI-RADS 3), another cystic lesion measuring 9 
mm × 6 mm (TI-RADS 2), and the isthmus was normal. 
In the left lobe a well-defined hyperechoic lesion (taller 
than wide) measuring 8 mm × 5  mm with internal 
microcalcification (TI-RADS 4) was detected. Another 
lesion in the left lobe was well defined as hyperechoic 
with central anechoic area providing a comet tail 
artifact (TI-RADS 2). A well-defined heterogeneous 
lesion measuring 12 mm × 9 mm in medial aspect of left 
carotid vessels inferior to left lobe of the thyroid gland 
was observed, with the possibility of being a parathyroid 
adenoma.
Ultrasound (USG)-guided fine-needle aspiration cytol ogy (FNAC) from right thyroid lesion showed features of 
adenomatous goiter (Bethesda category II showing focal 
reactive architectural and cytological atypia with abun dant colloid in the background). USG-guided FNAC 
from left thyroid lesion showed follicular epithelial cells 
arranged in clusters and microfollicles with focal nuclear 
enlargement, elongation, and occasional nuclear grooves 
and membrane irregularities. However, no definite pap illary fragments or cytoplasmic inclusions were seen. In 
the absence of conclusive evidence, a final impression of 
atypia of undetermined significance with architectural 
and cytological atypia was made (AUS A + C), Bethesda 
category III.
Later Tc99 MIBI Scintigraphy showed focal increased 
tracer uptake in the region of lower pole of left lobe of 
thyroid, which persists until delayed image. Findings 
were suggestive of left inferior parathyroid adenoma.Single photon emission computed tomography 
(SPECT–CT) showed enlarged both lobes of thyroid 
gland with physiological uptake and an 18 mm × 11 mm 
well-defined cystic nodule in the upper half of left lobe 
with tracer uptake. We have also noted a discrete 16 mm 
× 12  mm soft tissue density lesion in left paratracheal 
location inferior to the lower pole of the left lobe of the 
thyroid. Findings were suggestive of left inferior parathy roid adenoma.
A Dual energy X-ray Absorptiometry (DEXA) scan 
for skeletal survey was completed. An ultrasound of the 
abdomen showed no evidence of renal stones.
The patient underwent  total thyroidectomy with left 
inferior parathyroidectomy via collar incision. Intraoperatively, the left lobe of thyroid was enlarged with a 
nodule around 2 cm × 2  cm in size and the left inferior 
parathyroid gland was around 1 cm × 1.5 cm (Fig.  1b), 
which was sent as an intra-operative frozen section and 
found to be a parathyroid adenoma. The left superior 
parathyroid gland was identified and preserved. The 
right thyroid lobe was enlarged with a nodule measuring 
around 3 cm × 4 cm (Fig.  1c). Right superior parathyroid 
gland was identified and preserved, right inferior para thyroid could not be identified. Intra-operatively, 2.5 ml 
indocyaninegreen (ICG) dye was given intravenously; the 
right and left superior parathyroid glands were well visu alized by spy camera. Postoperative laryngoscopy showed 
bilateral mobile vocal cords. Postoperative Intact para thyroid hormone (iPTH) fell was from 253 to 10.7  pg/
ml (99.7%) and postoperative calcium was 9.7  mg/dl 
(Table 1).
The patient was discharged on postoperative day 
3 in stable condition on oral calcium and vitamin D 
supplements.
Final histopathology showed the existence of a  
parathyroid adenoma composed of both chief and 
oxyphil cells (Fig.  2A, B). The right lobe of the thyroid 
showed subacute granulomatous thyroiditis as well

on Zeihl–Neelson staining revealed presence of acidfast bacilli (Fig.  2C, D). A 5-mm nodule was identified in 
the isthmus, which on microscopy showed features of a

After a 6-month follow-up, the patient was doing well 
and with significant reduction in lower back and limb 
pain. She is taking antitubercular medications with com pliance and tolerating them well.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion
Tuberculosis is a global threat to public health. Accord ing to the World Health Organization (WHO) tuber culosis (TB) statistics of 2020, an estimated 10 million 
people were diagnosed with tuberculosis (TB) world wide. Over 95% of cases and deaths were reported in 
developing countries. It was estimated that about 40% of 
the Indian population is infected with tubercle bacilli; the 
vast majority of these individuals have latent TB rather 
than active tuberculosis. Tuberculosis (TB) may be cat egorized into pulmonary and extrapulmonary in origin. 
Extrapulmonary tuberculosis comprises 20% of all TB 
cases and occurs in a variety of organs [1].
Primary thyroid tuberculosis is rare with a frequency 
of 0.1–0.4% in histologically diagnosed thyroid specimen [2]. Thyroid TB is difficult to diagnose in the clinic due to 
the lack of specific signs and symptoms. It may be pre sented as an isolated nodule, diffuse lesion, multinodular 
goiter, or even as an abscess or chronic discharging sinus. 
Imaging techniques are not very useful in forming a diag nosis [3].
Majority of thyroid TB cases diagnosed are solely based 
on the postoperative histopathological examination.
In a case series of four thyroid tuberculosis cases by 
Khan et al. showed the diagnosis was a pathological sur prise in three cases with fine-needle aspiration in one 
and histopathology in two cases. Only one case present ing with chronic discharging sinus showed the presence 
of acid-fast bacilli. All cases showed multiple caseating 
epitheloid cell granulomas along with giant cells, which 
are considered to be diagnostic of tuberculous thyroiditis 
even if acid-fast bacilli cannot be demonstrated [4].
The coexistence of malignant lesions and TB at the 
same anatomical location in a patient is very rare but it 
has been reported in various organs. However, only four 
cases in which thyroid TB occurred concomitantly with 
thyroid cancer have been reported. Among them, three 
cases of thyroid TB were found postoperatively and one 
case was identified in the fine-needle aspiration cytology 
(FNAC) [5–8].

In the present case, histopathological findings revealed 
typical inflammatory characteristics of thyroid TB. Thus, 
the development of papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) 
may be associated with TB infection [9, 10].
There have been a few cases of coexistence of 
parathyroid adenoma and thyroid carcinoma reported, 
where researchers have indicated elevated calcium level 
as causative element for developing thyroid carcinoma 
[11]. There have been many studies on the correlation 
between primary hyperthyroidism and differentiated 
thyroid cancer. A retrospective study by Burmeister [12] 
in 824 patients of hyperparathyroidism, 22 patients found 
to have thyroid carcinoma at the time of parathyroid 
surgery. Thyroid carcinoma was found in 2.6% of the 
patients with primary and 3.2% of the patients with either 
secondary or tertiary hyperparathyroidism. Twenty one 
of the patients had papillary carcinoma and one had a 
follicular. Eighteen of the carcinomas were less than 1 cm 
in size.
Most of the researchers believes that it is a coincidence 
due to more advanced imaging in preoperative 
localization of parathyroid lesion and close surveillance. 
However, other researchers have indicated endogenous 
calcium levels or growth factors, for instance, insulin-like 
growth factors and epithelial growth factors, as elements 
causing goiter [11, 13].
It has also been found that patients who are of peri- 
and postmenopausal age have increased risk of thyroid 
nodule and thyroid cancer [14], as shown in our patient. 
Our patient was a known case of hypothyroidism 
for a long period of time, which may be the cause of 
developing thyroid cancer as shown in a study by Li 
et al., which showed the relationship between subclinical 
hypothyroidism and invasive papillary thyroid carcinoma 
based on the findings from the Gene Set Enrichment 
Analysis (GSEA) and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes 
and Genomes (KEGG), revealing the concentrationdependent relationship between thyroid-stimulating 
hormone (TSH) and key gene expression in the 
autophagy pathways of thyroid cancer cells [15]. These 
patients tend to have more extrathyroidal extension. A 
study by Cheg et al. showed the bidirectional relationship 
between tuberculosis and hypothyroidism. They have 
found that patients with hypothyroidism have a 2.91 
times higher risk of developing TB than those with 
hypothyroidism and that patients with TB have a 2.01 
times higher risk of developing hypothyroidism than 
those without, although the pathophysiology is remains 
unclear [16].
Interestingly in our case there was coexistence of 
thyroid carcinoma and thyroid tuberculosis, along with 
parathyroid adenoma, with a history of hypothyroidism 
for 13 years. To the best of our knowledge, a similar case has not been reported in the literature. Other possible 
hypotheses include immunity-related pathology, such 
as immunoglobulin (Ig) G-4, the role of some toxic and 
essential elements, post-transplant state, and other 
environmental factors.
In our case the probable mechanism could be chronic 
inflammation due to tuberculosis leading to development 
of thyroid cancer and parathyroid adenoma in the 
presence of hypothyroidism and perimenopausal state. 
Further studies need to be done to understand the exact 
mechanism of pathogenesis of the three coexisting 
pathologies.
Conclusion
It is quite uncommon for parathyroid adenoma, 
nonmedullary thyroid cancer, and thyroid tuberculosis 
to coexist. Surgery is the curative option preferred 
for thyroid cancer and hyperparathyroidism. Thyroid 
tuberculosis responds well to current antitubercular 
drugs. Further investigation is necessary to determine 
its origin, although one probable hypothesis is that 
latent tuberculosis-related chronic inflammation 
may contribute to the development of thyroid cancer 
and parathyroid adenoma. To better understand the 
underlying mechanism and provide better options for 
managing such patients, additional research needs to be 
done. As per our knowledge, no similar case report has 
been published in the literature until now.
